quest_title: The point on the parabola \(y ^ { 2 } = 8 x\) at which the normal is parallel to the line \(x - 2 y + 5 = 0\) is
explanation_txt:
The line parallel to \( x - 2y + 5 = 0 \) is \( x - 2y + k = 0 ... (i) \)

The equation of normal to \( y^2 = 8x \) is \( y = mx – 4m – 2m^3 ..... (ii)\)

Comparing (i) and (ii), \( m = 1/2 \), So, equation is \( y = 0.5x - 2 - 0.25 \Rightarrow y = 0.5x - 2.25 \)

Solving this line and the parabola, we get \( (x,y) = (1/2, -2 ) \)

explanation_txt:
\[ \int _{1}^{e}\cfrac{e^{x} }{x} (1+x\log x)dx \]

quest_title: The resultant of two forces (A + B) and (A -B) is \(\sqrt{3 A^{2}+B^{2}}\) then angle between two forces is
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{array}{l}{\mathrm{R}=\sqrt{(\mathrm{A}+\mathrm{B})^{2}+2(\mathrm{A}+\mathrm{B})(\mathrm{A}-\mathrm{B}) \cos \theta+(\mathrm{A}-\mathrm{B})^{2}}} \\ {\mathrm{Or}, \sqrt{3 \mathrm{A}^{2}+\mathrm{B}^{2}}=\sqrt{(\mathrm{A}+\mathrm{B})^{2}+2\left(\mathrm{A}^{2}-\mathrm{B}^{2}\right) \cos \theta+(\mathrm{A}-\mathrm{B})^{2}}}\end{array}\)

\(\begin{aligned} \text { Or, } 3 \mathrm{A}^{2}+\mathrm{B}^{2}=& \mathrm{A}^{2}+2 \mathrm{AB}+\mathrm{B}^{2}+2\left(\mathrm{A}^{2}-\mathrm{B}^{2}\right) \cos \theta \\ &+\mathrm{A}^{2}-2 \mathrm{AB}+\mathrm{B}^{2} \end{aligned}\)

\(\begin{array}{c}{\text { Or, } A^{2}-B^{2}=2\left(A^{2}-B^{2}\right) \cos \theta} \\ {\text { Or, } \cos \theta=1 / 2=\cos 60^{\circ}} \\ {\therefore \theta=60^{\circ}}\end{array}\)

quest_title: A police jeep is chasing with, velocity of 45 km/h a thief in another jeep moving with velocity 153 km/h. Police fires a bullet with muzzle velocity of 180 m/s. The velocity it will strike the car of the thief is
explanation_txt:
Effective speed of the bullet = speed of bullet + speed of police jeep

\(= 180 \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { s } + 45 \mathrm { km } / \mathrm { h } = ( 180 + 12.5 ) \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { s } = 192.5 \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { s }\)

Speed of thief ’s jeep \(= 153 \mathrm { km } / \mathrm { h } = 42.5 \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { s }\)

Velocity of bullet with respect to thief ’s \(= 192.5 - 42.5 = 150 m / s\)

quest_title: If \(a,\; b,\; c,\; d\) are in H.P., then \(ab+bc+cd\) is equal to
explanation_txt:
Since \(a,\; b,\; c,\; d\) are in H.P., therefore \(b\) is the H.M. of \(a\) and \(c\) \(i.e.\) \(b=\cfrac{2ac}{a+c} \) and \(c\) is the H.M. of \(b\) and \(d\) \(i.e.\)\(c=\cfrac{2bd}{b+d} \),

\({\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise4pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu} \) \[(a+c)(b+d)=\cfrac{2ac}{b} .\cfrac{2bd}{c} \]

\[\Rightarrow ab+ad+bc+cd=4ad\]

\[ \Rightarrow ab+bc+cd=3ad.\]

[Check for a known HP: 1,1/2,1/3,1/4,...]

The angle between two vectors of magnitudes (P + Q) and (P -Q) acting at a point so that their resultant is \(\sqrt{P^{2}+Q^{2}}\) is
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{array}{l}{\mathrm{R}=\sqrt{(\mathrm{P}+\mathrm{Q})^{2}+2(\mathrm{P}+\mathrm{Q})(\mathrm{P}-\mathrm{Q}) \cos \theta+(\mathrm{P}-\mathrm{Q})^{2}}} \\ {\sqrt{\mathrm{p}^{2}+\mathrm{Q}^{2}}=\sqrt{\mathrm{P}^{2}+2 \mathrm{PQ}+\mathrm{Q}^{2}+2\left(\mathrm{P}^{2}-\mathrm{Q}^{2}\right) \operatorname{Cos} \theta+\mathrm{P}^{2}-2 \mathrm{P} \mathrm{Q}+\mathrm{Q}^{2}}} \\ {\mathrm{Or}, \mathrm{P}^{2}+\mathrm{Q}^{2}=2 \mathrm{P}^{2}+2 \mathrm{Q}^{2}+2\left(\mathrm{P}^{2}-\mathrm{Q}^{2}\right) \cos \theta} \\ {\mathrm{Or},-\mathrm{P}^{2}-\mathrm{Q}^{2}=2\left(\mathrm{P}^{2}-\mathrm{Q}^{2}\right) \cos \theta}\end{array}\)

\(\begin{array}{l}{\mathrm{Or}, \cos \theta=\cfrac{\mathrm{P}^{2}+\mathrm{Q}^{2}}{2\left(\mathrm{Q}^{2}-\mathrm{P}^{2}\right)}} \\ {\therefore \theta=\cos ^{-1}\left\{\cfrac{\mathrm{p}^{2}+\mathrm{Q}^{2}}{2\left(\mathrm{Q}^{2}-\mathrm{P}^{2}\right)}\right\}}\end{array}\)

quest_title: A force of 1 N is required to stretch a long spring by 1.5cm. This spring is cut in 3 equal parts. The force required to stretch 3cm to one part is
explanation_txt:
\(\quad\)When a spring is cut in 3 equal parts then spring constant become 3 times.

\(\quad\)First case

\(\quad\)\(\quad\)\(F\) = \(Kx\)

\(\quad\)Or,\(\quad\)1 = \(K\) \(\times \) 1.5

\(\quad\)Or,\(\quad\)\(K\) = \( \cfrac{1}{1.5} \)

\(\quad\)Second case

\(\quad\)\(\quad\)\(F'\) = 3\(Kx'\) = \(3 \times \) \( \cfrac{1}{1.5} \)\(\times \) 3 = 6 N

explanation_plain_text:

First case

=

= 3 = 3 = 6 N

quest_title: A 60 kg body is pushed with just enough force to start it moving across a floor and the same force continues to act afterwards. The coefficient of static friction and sliding friction are 0.5 and 0.4 respectively. The acceleration of the body is
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{array} { l } { \text { Limiting friction } = \mu _ { s } R = \mu _ { s } m g = 0.5 \times 60 \times 10 = 300 N } \\ { \text { Kinetic friction } = \mu _ { k } R = \mu _ { k } m g = 0.4 \times 60 \times 10 = 240 \mathrm { N } } \end{array}\)

Force applied on the body = 300 N and if the body is moving then,

Net accelerating force = Applied force - Kinetic friction

\(\Rightarrow m a = 300 - 240 = 60 \quad \therefore a = \cfrac { 60 } { 60 } = 1 \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { s } ^ { 2 }\)
question_plain_title: A 60 kg body is pushed with just enough force to start it moving across a floor and the same force continues to act afterwards. The coefficient of static friction and sliding friction are 0.5 and 0.4 respectively. The acceleration of the body is
explanation_plain_text:
Force applied on the body = 300 N and if the body is moving then,

Net accelerating force = Applied force - Kinetic friction

or, \(\mathrm{v}=\sqrt{\cfrac{I \omega^{2}}{m}}\)

quest_title: Let u denote one atomic mass unit. One atom of an element of mass number A has mass exactly equal to A u
ans4_txt: for any value of A provided the atom is stable
explanation_txt:
This is only true for Hydrogen atom because nucleus of hydrogen consists of only one proton with no neutron.

\(\therefore\) Mass of hydrogen atom = 1 amu

Atomic number of Hydrogen = no. of proton or electron in an atom = 1

All other atoms have at least one neutron (mass = 1 amu, charge = 0) in their nucleus by which atomic number and mass number differs.
question_plain_title: Let u denote one atomic mass unit. One atom of an element of mass number A has mass exactly equal to A u
explanation_plain_text:
This is only true for Hydrogen atom because nucleus of hydrogen consists of only one proton with no neutron.

Mass of hydrogen atom = 1 amu

Atomic number of Hydrogen = no. of proton or electron in an atom = 1

All other atoms have at least one neutron (mass = 1 amu, charge = 0) in their nucleus by which atomic number and mass number differs.
ans4_plain_text: for any value of A provided the atom is stable

quest_title: Domain of \( f ( x ) = \log ( \sqrt { x - 4 } + \sqrt { 6 - x } ) \) is
explanation_txt: \( \begin{array} { l } { f ( x ) = \log ( \sqrt { x } - 4 + \sqrt { 6 } - x ) } \\ { \Rightarrow x - 4 \geq 0 \text { and } 6 - x \geq 0 \Rightarrow x \geq 4 \text { and } x \leq 6 } \\ { \therefore \text { Domain of } f ( x ) = [ 4,6 ] } \end{array} \)

quest_title: The most powerful reducing agent is.
explanation_txt:
The electrochemical series from top to bottom order is:

Li, K, Ca, Na, Mg, Al, Zn, Fe, Pb, H2, Cu, Ag, Au

It is the ascending order of tendency of being reduced. Thus the first ones in the series have the most tendency of being oxidized, thus having the most oxidizing power.

Hence, K is the most powerful reducing agent among the four.
question_plain_title: The most powerful reducing agent is.
explanation_plain_text:
The electrochemical series from top to bottom order is:

Li, K, Ca, Na, Mg, Al, Zn, Fe, Pb, H2, Cu, Ag, Au

It is the ascending order of tendency of being reduced. Thus the first ones in the series have the most tendency of being oxidized, thus having the most oxidizing power.

Hence, K is the most powerful reducing agent among the four.

quest_title: Dichromate oxidizes sulphurous acid to sulphuric acid. How does the oxidation state of sulphur change?
explanation_txt: \(\underset{Sulphurous\, Acid}{H_2\overset{+4}SO_3} \to \underset{Sulphuric \,Acid}{H_2\overset{+6}SO_4}\)

quest_title: A ray reflected successively from two plane mirror inclined at certain angle undergoes a deviation of 240\({}^{o}\). The number of images formed are
explanation_txt:
\(\delta=360^{\circ}-2 \theta\)
or \(, 2 \theta=360^{\circ}-240^{\circ}=120^{\circ}\)
or, \(\theta=\cfrac{120}{2}=60^{\circ}\)
\(\therefore\) No of image \((\mathrm{n})=\cfrac{360}{\theta}-1=\cfrac{360}{60}-1=5\)

quest_title: Two charged spheres separated at a distance d exert a force on each other. If they are immersed in a liquid of dielectric constant 2, then what is the force (if all conditions are same)
explanation_txt:
\(F \propto \cfrac { 1 } { K } \text { i.e. } \cfrac { F _ { \text {medium} } } { F _ { \text {air} } } = \cfrac { 1 } { K }\)

\(\therefore F_{liquid}=\cfrac{F}{2}\)

quest_title: Ionic bond is highly favoured between
explanation_txt: Cations lose electrons and anions gain them. When the size of a cation is larger, it is easier to lose the ourtermost electrons due to being far from the nucleus and also due to the shielding effects of the inner-shell electrons. And on the other hand, if the size of an anion is smaller, it will be easier to attract thus gain electrons due to greater nuclear pull.
question_plain_title: Ionic bond is highly favoured between
explanation_plain_text: Cations lose electrons and anions gain them. When the size of a cation is larger, it is easier to lose the ourtermost electrons due to being far from the nucleus and also due to the shielding effects of the inner-shell electrons. And on the other hand, if the size of an anion is smaller, it will be easier to attract thus gain electrons due to greater nuclear pull.

quest_title:
How many real roots does the following equation have?

\[x-\cfrac{2}{x-1} =1-\cfrac{2}{x-1} \]
explanation_txt:
For the equation to be defined, \( x \ne 1 \).

Then, multilpying with \( x - 1\) on both sides,

\( x(x-1) - 2 = (x-1) - 2 \)

which simplifies to:

\( (x-1)^2 = 0 \)

But considering \(x \ne 1 \), this equation has no roots.

quest_title: If a , b and a - b are all unit vectors, the angle between a and b is:
explanation_txt:
\( \mathbb{a} - \mathbb{b} \) is unit.

So, \( (\mathbb{a} - \mathbb{b} )^2 = 1 \)

Or, \( 1 + 1 -2 \cos(x) = 1 \)

Or, \( \cos(x) = \cfrac{1}{2} \)

So, \( x = 60^{\circ} \)

So, the limit is 1.

quest_title: A physical quantity \(x\) depends on quantities \(y\) and \(z\) as follows: \(x = A y + B \tan C z ,\) where \(A , B\) and \(C\) are constants. Which of the following do not have the same dimensions?
explanation_txt:
\( x = A y + B \tan C z\)

From the dimensional homogeneity,

\( [ x ] = [ A y ] = [ B ] \Rightarrow \left[ \cfrac { x } { A } \right] = [ v ] = \left[ \cfrac { B } { A } \right]\)

\( [ C z ] = \left[ M ^ { 0 } L ^ { 0 } T ^ { 0 } \right] = \text { Dimensionless } \)

\( x \text { and } B ; C \text { and } Z ^ { - 1 } ; y \text { and } \cfrac { B } { A } \) have the same dimension but \(x\) and \(A\) have the different dimensions.

have the same dimension but and have the different dimensions.

quest_title: Certain neutron stars are believed to be rotating at about 1 rev/s. If such a star has a radius of 20km. The acceleration of object at equator of star will be
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} \mathrm{a} &=\mathrm{r} \omega^{2} \\ &=20 \times 10^{3} \times(2 \pi \mathrm{f})^{2} \\ &=7.9 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \end{aligned}\)

ans3_plain_text: 810 m/s
ans4_plain_text: 410 m/s

quest_title: A uniform chain of length 2 m is kept on a table such that a length of 60 cm hangs freely from the edge of table. The total mass of chain is 4 kg then work done to pull entire chain on table is
explanation_txt:
\(\quad\)Work done (\(W\)) = Increase in PE

\(\quad\) = \( \left(\cfrac{M}{L} \times l\right) \)\(g\) \(\times \) \( \cfrac{l}{2} \)

\(\quad\) = \( \left(\cfrac{4}{2}\right) \)\(\times \) \(0.6 \times \) \(10 \times \) \( \cfrac{0.6}{2} \)

\(\quad\) = 3.6 J

quest_title: Two bullets are fired horizontally with velocity u\({}_{1}\) and u\({}_{2}\) in opposite direction from top tower. The time after which their velocity become perpendicular to each other is
explanation_txt:
\(\overrightarrow{\mathrm{V}_{1}} \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathrm{V}_{2}}=0\)

\(\text { or, }\left(u_{1} \hat{i}-g t \hat{j}\right) \cdot\left(-u_{2} \hat{i}-g t \hat{j}\right)=0 \)
\(\text { or, }-u_{1} u_{2}+g^{2} t^{2}=0 \)
\(\text { or, } t=\cfrac{\sqrt{u_{1} u_{2}}}{g} \)
question_plain_title: Two bullets are fired horizontally with velocity u and u in opposite direction from top tower. The time after which their velocity become perpendicular to each other is

quest_title: In Young's double slit experiment how many maxima can be obtained on a screen (including the central maximum) on both sides of the central fringe if \(\text{\(\lambda\)}\) = 2000 \(\mathring{A}\) and \(\text{d}\) = 7000 \(\mathring{A}\)?
explanation_txt:
\(\quad\)dsin\(\theta \)\(_{n}\) = n\(\lambda \)

\(\quad\)For maximum order sin\(\theta \)\(_{n}\) = 1

\(\quad\)\(\therefore \) n = \( \cfrac{d}{\lambda } = \cfrac{7000\times 10^{-10}}{2000\times 10^{-10}} \) = 3.5

\(\quad\)Total 3 maxima are obtained above & 3 below the central maxima so

\(\quad\)n = 3 + 3 + 1 = 7
question_plain_title: In Young's double slit experiment how many maxima can be obtained on a screen (including the central maximum) on both sides of the central fringe if = 2000 and = 7000 ?
explanation_plain_text:
dsin = n

For maximum order sin = 1

n = = 3.5

Total 3 maxima are obtained above & 3 below the central maxima so

n = 3 + 3 + 1 = 7

quest_title: A long straight wire is carrying a current of 25 A. A rectangular coil of length 25 cm and breadth 10 cm, carrying a current of 15 A, is placed 2 cm from the wire as shown in figure. The force on the coil is
explanation_txt:
The forces on \(\mathrm{AC}\) and \(\mathrm{GD}\) are equal and opposite. So they cancel each other.

Force on side \(\mathrm{AG}, F_{1}=\cfrac{\mu_{0} i_{1} i_{2} l}{2 \pi r_{1}} \text { towards left } \)

Force on side \(\mathrm{CD}, F_{2}=\cfrac{\mu_{0} i_{1} i_{2} l}{2 \pi r_{2}} \text { towards right } \)

\(\text { Net force } F=F_{1}-F_{2}=\cfrac{\mu_{0} i_{1} i_{2} l}{2 \pi}\left(\cfrac{1}{r_{1}}-\cfrac{1}{r_{2}}\right) \)

\(=2 \times 10^{-7} \times 25 \times 15 \times 0.25\left(\cfrac{1}{0.02}-\cfrac{1}{0.12}\right) \)

\(=7.8 \times 10^{-4} \text { towards left. } \)
question_plain_title: A long straight wire is carrying a current of 25 A. A rectangular coil of length 25 cm and breadth 10 cm, carrying a current of 15 A, is placed 2 cm from the wire as shown in figure. The force on the coil is
explanation_plain_text:
The forces on and are equal and opposite. So they cancel each other.

Force on side

Force on side
ans1_plain_text: 7.8 10 N towards the wire
ans2_plain_text: 7.8 10 N away from the wire
ans3_plain_text: 9.4 10 N towards the wire
ans4_plain_text: 9.4 10 N away from the wire

quest_title: Radio station can be tune 880kHz to 1200kHz. The inductance is 200\(\mu\)H then range of capacitance is
explanation_txt:
\(f_0 = \cfrac{1}{2\pi \sqrt{LC}}\)

or, \(C = \cfrac{1}{4\pi^2 f_0^2 L} = \cfrac{1}{4 \pi^2 (880 \times 10^3)^2 \times 200 \times 10^{-6}} \\ \quad = 163PF\)

And,

\(\begin{align} C' & = \cfrac{1}{4\pi^2 f_0'^2 L} \\ & = \cfrac{1}{4\pi^2 (1200 \times 10^3)^2 \times 200 \times 10^{-6}} \\ & = 88PF \end{align}\)

\(\therefore\) Range \(=163PF\) to \(88PF\)

quest_title: The points (3a, 0), (0, 3b) and (a, 2b) are vertices of
ans3_txt: Vertices of a right angled isosceles triangle
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{array} { l } { l _ { 1 } = \sqrt { ( 3 a ) ^ { 2 } + ( 3 b ) ^ { 2 } } = 3 \sqrt { a ^ { 2 } + b ^ { 2 } } } \\ { l _ { 2 } = \sqrt { a ^ { 2 } + b ^ { 2 } } = \sqrt { a ^ { 2 } + b ^ { 2 } } } \\ { l _ { 3 } = \sqrt { ( 2 a ) ^ { 2 } + ( 2 b ) ^ { 2 } } = 2 \sqrt { a ^ { 2 } + b ^ { 2 } } \Rightarrow l _ { 1 } = l _ { 2 } + l _ { 3 } } \end{array}\)

Hence the points are collinear
question_plain_title: The points (3a, 0), (0, 3b) and (a, 2b) are vertices of
explanation_plain_text: Hence the points are collinear
ans3_plain_text: Vertices of a right angled isosceles triangle

quest_title: \(\text{H\(_{2}\)O}\) can act as either acid or base , which of the following reactions best illustrates the behavior of water as the base?
explanation_txt:
\(\underset{strong\,acid}{HCl} + \underset{weak \,base}{H_2O} \to \underset{strong\,conjugate\,acid}{H_3O^+} +\underset{weak \,conjugate\, base}{Cl^-}\)

In this reaction water received a proton to form a stronger conjugate acid.

In option c and d, it is acting as an acid as it  has donated a proton.
question_plain_title: can act as either acid or base , which of the following reactions best illustrates the behavior of water as the base?
explanation_plain_text:
In this reaction water received a proton to form a stronger conjugate acid.

In option c and d, it is acting as an acid as it  has donated a proton.
ans1_plain_text: HCl + + Cl¯
ans2_plain_text: HCl + NaON NaCl +
ans3_plain_text: + + OH¯
ans4_plain_text: + + OH¯
